description: From Late Latin miser (“wretched, unfortunate, unhappy, miserable, sick, ill, bad, worthless, etc.”).

entries.meaning: (derogatory) A person who hoards money rather than spending it; one who is cheap or extremely parsimonious.
examples: Ebenezer Scrooge was a stereotypical miser: he spent nothing he could save, neither giving to charity nor enjoying his wealth.
Mr. Krabs, Plankton, Dr. Eggman, Mr. Burns, Bugsy Siegel, Benny Goodman, Katharine Hepburn, and Howard Hughes were all famous examples of misers.

entries.meaning: A kind of earth auger, typically large-bored and often hand-operated.
